In order to bring quantum networks into the real world, we would like to determine the

line_1.text: requirements of quantum network protocols including the underlying quantum hardware.

line_2.text: Because detailed architecture proposals are generally too complex for mathematical analysis,

line_3.text: it is natural to employ numerical simulation. Here we introduce NetSquid, the NETwork

line_4.text: Simulator for QUantum Information using Discrete events, a discrete-event based platform

line_5.text: for simulating all aspects of quantum networks and modular quantum computing systems,

line_6.text: ranging from the physical layer and its control plane up to the application level. We study

line_7.text: several use cases to showcase NetSquidâ€™s power, including detailed physical layer simula-

line_8.text: tions of repeater chains based on nitrogen vacancy centres in diamond as well as atomic

line_9.text: ensembles. We also study the control plane of a quantum switch beyond its analytically

line_10.text: known regime, and showcase NetSquidâ€™s ability to investigate large networks by simulating

line_11.text: entanglement distribution over a chain of up to one thousand nodes.

Quantum communication can be used to connect distant
quantum devices into a quantum network. At short dis-

line_1.text: tances, networking quantum devices provides a path

line_2.text: towards a scalable distributed quantum computer1. At larger

line_3.text: distances, interconnected quantum networks allow for commu-

line_4.text: nication tasks between distant users on a quantum internet. Both

line_5.text: types of quantum networks have the potential for large societal

line_6.text: impact. First, analogous to classical computers, it is likely that any

line_7.text: approach for scaling up a quantum computer so that it can solve

line_8.text: real world problems impractical to treat on a classical computer,

line_9.text: will require the interconnection of different modules2â€“4. Fur-

line_10.text: thermore, quantum communication networks enable a host of

line_11.text: tasks that are impossible using classical communication5.

line_1.text: before they can fulï¬l their promise. The exact extent of these

line_4.text: the physical layer, many proposals exist for quantum repeaters

Quantum networks cannot be built from quantum hardware

line_1.text: alone; in order to scale they need a tightly integrated classical

line_2.text: control plane, i.e. protocols responsible for orchestrating quantum

line_3.text: network devices to bring entanglement to users. Fundamental

line_4.text: differences between quantum and classical information demand

line_5.text: an entirely new network stack in order to create entanglement,

line_6.text: and run useful applications on future quantum networks39â€“44. The

line_7.text: design of such a control stack is furthermore made challenging by

line_8.text: numerous technological limitations of quantum devices. A good

line_9.text: example is given by the limited lifetimes of quantum memories,

line_10.text: due to which delays in the exchange of classical control messages

line_11.text: have a direct impact on the performance of the network. To

line_12.text: succeed, we hence need to understand how possible classical

line_13.text: control strategies do perform on speciï¬c quantum hardware.

line_14.text: Finally, to guide overall development, we need to understand the

line_15.text: requirements of quantum network applications themselves. Apart

line_16.text: from quantum key distribution (QKD)45â€“49 and a few select

Analytical tools offer only a limited solution for our needs.

line_1.text: Statistical tools (see e.g.54â€“57) have been used to make predictions

line_2.text: about certain aspects of large regular networks using simpliï¬ed

line_3.text: models, but are of limited use for more detailed studies. Infor-

line_4.text: mation theory58 can be used to benchmark implementations

line_5.text: against the ideal performance. However, it gives no information

line_6.text: about how well a speciï¬c proposal will perform. As a con-

line_7.text: sequence, numerical methods are of great use to go beyond what

line_8.text: is feasible using an analytical study. Ad-hoc simulations of

line_9.text: quantum networks have indeed been used to provide further

line_10.text: insights on speciï¬c aspects of quantum networks (see e.-

line_11.text: g.31â€“38,59â€“61). However, while greatly informative, setting up ad-

line_12.text: hoc simulations for each possible networking scenario to a level of

line_13.text: detail

line_14.text: that might allow the determination of more precise

line_15.text: requirements is cumbersome, and does not straightforwardly lend

line_16.text: itself to extensive explorations of new possibilities.

line_0.text: We would hence like a simulation platform that satisï¬es at least

line_1.text: the following three features: First, accuracy: the tool should allow

line_0.text: modelling the relevant physics. This includes the ability to model

line_1.text: time-dependent noise and network behaviour. Second, mod-

line_2.text: ularity: it should allow stacking protocols and models together in

line_3.text: order to construct complicated network simulations out of simple

line_4.text: components. This includes the ability to investigate not only the

line_5.text: physical layer hardware, but the entirety of the quantum network

line_6.text: system including how different control protocols behave on a

line_7.text: given hardware setup. Third, scalability: it should allow us to

line_8.text: investigate large networks.

line_0.text: Evaluating the performance of large classical network systems,

line_1.text: including their time-dependent behaviour is the essence of clas-

line_2.text: sical network analysis. Yet, even for classical networks, the pre-

line_3.text: dictive power of analytical methods is limited due to complex

line_4.text: emergent behaviour arising from the interplay between many

line_5.text: network devices. Consequently, a crucial tool in the design of

line_6.text: such networks are network simulators, which form a tool to test

line_7.text: new ideas, and many such simulators exist for purely classical

line_8.text: networks62â€“64. However, such simulators do not allow the

line_9.text: simulation of quantum behaviour.

line_0.text: In the quantum domain, many simulators are known for the

line_1.text: simulation of quantum computers (see e.g.65). However, the task

line_2.text: of simulating a quantum network differs greatly from simulating

line_3.text: the execution of one monolithic quantum system. In the network,

line_4.text: many devices are communicating with each other both quan-

line_5.text: tumly and classically, leading to complex stochastic behaviour,

line_6.text: and asynchronous and time-dependent events. From the per-

line_7.text: spective of building a simulation engine, there is also an impor-

line_8.text: tant difference that allows for gains in the efï¬ciency of the

line_9.text: simulation. A simulator for a quantum computation is optimised

line_10.text: to track large entangled states. In contrast, in a quantum network

line_11.text: the state space grows and shrinks dynamically as qubits get

line_12.text: measured or entangled, but for many protocols, at any moment in

line_13.text: time the state space describing the quantum state of the network

line_14.text: is small. We would thus like a simulator capable of exploiting this

line_15.text: advantage.

line_0.text: In this paper we introduce the quantum network simulator

line_1.text: NetSquid: the NETwork Simulator for QUantum Information

line_2.text: using Discrete events. NetSquid is a software tool (available as a

line_3.text: package for Python and previously made freely available online66)

line_4.text: for accurately simulating quantum networking and modular

line_5.text: computing systems that are subject to physical non-idealities. It

line_6.text: achieves this by integrating several key technologies: a discrete-

line_7.text: event simulation engine, a specialised quantum computing

line_8.text: library, a modular framework for modelling quantum hardware

line_9.text: devices, and an asynchronous programming framework for

line_10.text: describing quantum protocols. We showcase the utility of this

line_11.text: tool for a range of applications by studying several use cases: the

line_12.text: analysis of a control plane protocol beyond its analytically

line_13.text: accessible regime, predicting the performance of protocols on

line_14.text: realistic near-term hardware, and benchmarking different quan-

line_15.text: tum devices. These use cases, in combination with a scalability

line_16.text: analysis, demonstrate that NetSquid achieves all three features set

line_17.text: forth above. Furthermore, they show its potential as a general and

line_18.text: versatile design tool for quantum networks, as well as for modular

line_0.text: Results and discussion

line_1.text: NetSquid in a nutshell. Simulating a quantum network with

line_2.text: NetSquid is generally performed in three steps. Firstly, the net-

line_3.text: work is modelled using a modular framework of components and

line_4.text: physical models. Next, protocols are assigned to network nodes to

line_5.text: describe the intended behaviour. Finally, the simulation is exe-

line_6.text: cuted for a typically large number of independent runs to collect

line_7.text: statistics with which to determine the performance of the net-

line_8.text: work. To explain these steps and the features involved further, we

Fig. 2 Abstract example of simulating a quantum protocol with discrete events. When setting up the simulation, protocol actions are deï¬ned to occur

line_1.text: when a speciï¬c event occurs, as in the setup of a real system. Instead of performing a continuous time evolution, the simulation advances to the next event,

line_2.text: and then automatically executes the actions that should occur when the event takes place. Any action may again deï¬ne future events to be triggered after a

line_3.text: certain (stochastic) amount of time has elapsed. For concreteness a simpliï¬ed quantum teleportation example is shown where a qubit, shown as an orange

line_4.text: circle with arrow, is teleported between the quantum memories of Alice and Bob. Here, entanglement is produced using an abstract source sending two

line_5.text: qubits, shown as blue circles with arrows, to Alice and Bob. Once the qubit has traversed the ï¬bre and reaches Aliceâ€™s lab, an event is triggered that invokes

line_6.text: the simulation of Aliceâ€™s Bell state measurement (BSM) apparatus. The simulation engine steps from event to events deï¬ned by the next action, which

line_7.text: generally occur at irregular intervals. This approach allows time-dependent physical non-idealities, such as quantum decoherence, to be accurately tracked.

line_0.text: Discrete-event simulation, an established method for simulat-

line_1.text: ing classical network systems68, is a modelling paradigm that

line_2.text: progresses time by stepping through a sequence of eventsâ€”see

line_3.text: Fig. 2 for a visual explanation. This allows the simulation engine

line_4.text: to efï¬ciently handle the control processes and feedback loops

line_5.text: characteristic of quantum networking systems, while tracking

line_6.text: quantum state decoherence based on the elapsed time between

line_7.text: events. A novel requirement for its application to quantum

line_8.text: networks is the need to accurately evolve the state of the quantum

line_9.text: information present in a network with time. This can be achieved

line_10.text: by retroactively updating quantum states when the associated

line_11.text: qubits are accessed during an event. While it is possible to

line_12.text: efï¬ciently track a density matrix, quantum operations requiring a

line_13.text: singular outcome for classical decision making, for instance a

line_14.text: quantum measurement, must be probabilistically sampled. A

line_15.text: single simulation run thus consists of a sequence of random

line_16.text: choices that forms one of many possible paths. In Fig. 1d we show

line_17.text: such a run for the repeater protocol example, which demonstrates

line_18.text: the power of the discrete-event approach for tracking qubit

line_0.text: The performance metrics of a simulation are determined

line_1.text: statistically from many runs. Due to the independence of each

line_2.text: run, simulations can be massively parallelised and thereby

line_3.text: efï¬ciently executed on computing clusters. For the example at

line_4.text: hand we choose as metrics the output ï¬delity and run duration.

line_5.text: In Fig. 1f the sampled run from Fig. 1d, which resulted in perfect

line_6.text: ï¬delity, is plotted in terms of its likelihood and duration together

line_7.text: with several other samples, some less successful. By statistically

line_8.text: averaging all of the sampled runs the output ï¬delity and duration

line_9.text: can be estimated.

line_0.text: Simulating a quantum network switch beyond its analytically

line_1.text: known regime. As a ï¬rst use case showcasing the power of

line_2.text: NetSquid, we study the control plane of a recently introduced

line_3.text: quantum switch beyond the regime for which analytical results

line_4.text: have been obtained,

line_5.text: including its performance under time-

line_6.text: dependent memory noise.

line_0.text: The switch is a node which is directly connected to each of k

line_1.text: users by an optical link. The communications task is distributing

line_2.text: Bell pairs and n-partite Greenbergerâ€“Horneâ€“Zeilinger (GHZ)

line_3.text: states69 between n â‰¤ k users. The switch achieves

line_4.text: this by

line_5.text: connecting Bell pairs which are generated at random intervals

line_6.text: on each link (See Fig. 3).

line_0.text: Intuitively, the switch can be regarded as a generalisation of a

line_1.text: simple repeater performing entanglement swapping with added

line_2.text: logic to choose which parties to link. Even with a streamlined

line_3.text: physical model, it is already rather challenging to analytically

line_4.text: characterise the switch use case56.

line_0.text: In the following, we recover via simulation a selection of the

line_1.text: results from Vardoyan et al.56, who studied the switch as the

line_2.text: central node in a star network, and extend them in two directions.

line_3.text: First, we increase the range of parameters for which we can

line_4.text: estimate entanglement rates using the same model as used in the

line_5.text: work of Vardoyan et al. Second, simulation enables us to

line_6.text: investigate more sophisticated models than the exponentially

line_7.text: distributed erasure process from their work,

line_8.text: in particular we

line_9.text: analyse the behaviour of a switch in the presence of memory

line_10.text: dephasing noise.

line_0.text: in contrast
The NV-based quantum processor includes the following three

line_1.text: features. First, the nodes have a single communication qubit, i.e. a

line_2.text: qubit acting as the optical interface that can be entangled with a

line_3.text: remote qubit via photon interference. This seemingly small

line_4.text: restriction has important consequences for the communications

line_5.text: protocol. In particular, entanglement can not proceed in parallel

line_6.text: with both adjacent nodes. As a consequence, operations need to be

line_7.text: scheduled in sequence and the state of the communication qubit

line_8.text: transferred onto a storage qubit. Second, the qubits in a node are

line_9.text: connected with a star topology with the communication qubit

line_10.text: located in the centre. Two-qubit gates are only possible between the

line_11.text: communication qubit and a storage qubit. Third, communication

line_12.text: and storage qubits have unequal coherence times. Furthermore, the

line_13.text: storage qubits suffer additional decoherence when the node

line_14.text: attempts to generate entanglement. Previous repeater-chain ana-

line_15.text: lyses, e.g.22,23,43, did not take all three into account simultaneously.

line_16.text: Together with the node model, we consider two protocols:

line_18.text: as soon as adjacent links are generated the entanglement is

line_19.text: swapped. NESTED-WITH-DISTILL is a nested protocol9 with

line_20.text: entanglement distillation at every nesting level. For a description

line_21.text: of the simulation, including the node model and protocols, see

line_22.text: Methods, section â€˜Implementing a processing-node repeater

line_0.text: The ï¬rst question that we investigate is the distance that can be

line_1.text: covered by a repeater chain. For this we choose two sets of

line_2.text: hardware parameters that we dub near-term and 10Ã— improved

line_3.text: (see Supplementary Note 4) and choose two conï¬gurations: one

line_4.text: without intermediate repeaters and one with three of them. We

line_5.text: observe, see Fig. 5a, that the repeater chain performs worse in

line_6.text: ï¬delity than the repeaterless conï¬guration with near-term

line_7.text: hardware. For improved hardware, we see two regimes, for short

line_8.text: distances the use of repeaters increases rate but lowers ï¬delity

line_9.text: while from 750 km until 1500 km the repeater chain outperforms

line_10.text: the no-repeater setup.

line_0.text: The second question that we address is which protocol

line_1.text: performs best for a given distance. We consider seven protocols:

line_2.text: no repeater, and repeater chains implementing SWAP-ASAP or

line_3.text: NESTED-WITH-DISTILL over 1, 3 or 7 repeaters. The latter is

line_4.text: motivated by the fact that the NESTED-WITH-DISTILL protocol

line_0.text: Performance

line_1.text: comparison between two atomic-ensemble

line_2.text: memory types through NetSquidâ€™s modular design. Finally,

line_3.text: we showcase that NetSquidâ€™s modular design greatly reduces the

line_4.text: effort of assessing possible hardware development scenarios. We

line_5.text: demonstrate the power of this modularity by simulating point-to-

line_6.text: point remote-entanglement generation based on either of two

line_7.text: types of atomic-ensemble based quantum memories: atomic fre-

line_8.text: quency combs (AFC)72 and electronically induced transparency

line_9.text: (EIT)73,74 memories. Both simulations are identical except for the

line_10.text: choice of a different quantum memory component.

line_0.text: The two types of memories are a promising building block for

line_1.text: high-rate remote entanglement generation through quantum

line_2.text: repeaters because of their high efï¬ciency (EIT) or their ability for

line_3.text: multiplexing (AFC), i.e. to perform many attempts at entangle-

line_4.text: ment generation simultaneously without network components

line_5.text: having to wait for the arrival of classical messages that herald

line_6.text: successful generation. The ï¬rst type of memories, AFCs, are based

line_7.text: on a photon-echo process, where an absorbed photon is re-

line_8.text: emitted after an engineered duration. In contrast, the second type,

line_9.text: EITs, emit the photon after an on-demand interval, due to optical

line_10.text: control. In principle the AFC protocol can be extended to offer

line_11.text: such on-demand retrieval as well. At this point both technologies

line_12.text: are promising candidates and it is not yet clear which outper-

line_13.text: forms the other and under what circumstances.

line_0.text: Atomic-ensemble based repeaters have been analytically and

line_1.text: numerically studied before with streamlined physical models19,75.

line_2.text: NetSquidâ€™s discrete-event based paradigm allows us to go beyond

line_3.text: that by concurrently introducing several non-ideal characteristics.

line_4.text: In particular, we include the emission of more than one photon

line_5.text: pair, photon distinguishability and time-dependent memory

line_6.text: efï¬ciency. Efï¬ciency in this context is the probability that the

line_7.text: absorbed photon will be re-emitted. All these characteristics have

line_8.text: a signiï¬cant impact on the performance of the repeater protocol.

line_9.text: In order to compare the two memory types, we simulate many

line_10.text: rounds of the BB84 quantum key distribution protocol76 between

line_11.text: two remote nodes, using a single repeater positioned precisely in

line_12.text: between them. Entanglement generation is attempted in syn-

line_13.text: chronised rounds over both segments in parallel. At the end of

line_14.text: each round, the two end nodes measure in the X- or Z-basis,

line_15.text: chosen uniformly at random, and the repeater performs a

line_16.text: probabilistic linear-optical Bell-state measurement. Upon a

line_17.text: successful outcome, we expect correlation between the measure-

line_18.text: ment outcomes if they were performed in the same basis. As a

line_19.text: ï¬gure of merit we choose the asymptotic BB84 secret-key rate.

We note that beyond 700 km the entanglement rate decreases

line_1.text: when the hardware is improved. This is due to the presence of

line_2.text: dark counts, i.e. false signals that a photon has been detected. At

line_3.text: large distances most photons dissipate in the ï¬bre, whereby the

line_4.text: majority of detector clicks are dark counts. Because a dark count

line_5.text: is mistakenly counted as a successful entanglement generation

line_6.text: attempt, improving (i.e. decreasing) the dark count rate in fact

line_8.text: the (perceived) entanglement rate plotted in Fig. 5a is calculated.

line_0.text: Fast and scalable quantum network simulation. NetSquid has

line_1.text: been designed and optimised to meet several key performance

line_2.text: criteria: to be capable of accurate physical modelling, to be

line_0.text: scalable to large networks, and to be sufï¬ciently fast to support

line_1.text: multi-variate design analyses with adequate statistics. While it is

line_2.text: not always possible to jointly satisfy all the criteria for all use

line_3.text: cases, NetSquidâ€™s design allows the user to prioritise them. We

line_4.text: proceed to benchmark NetSquid to demonstrate its capabilities

line_5.text: and unique strengths for quantum network simulation.

line_0.text: Benchmarking of quantum computation. To accurately model

line_1.text: physical non-idealities, it is necessary to choose a representation

line_2.text: for quantum states that allows a characterisation of general

line_3.text: processes such as amplitude damping, general measurements, or

line_4.text: arbitrary rotations. NetSquid provides two representations, or

line_5.text: â€˜formalismsâ€™, that are capable of universal quantum computation:

line_6.text: ket state vectors (KET) and density matrices, both stored using

line_7.text: dense arrays. The resource requirements for storage in memory

line_8.text: and the computation time associated with applying quantum

line_9.text: operations both scale exponentially with the number of qubits.

line_10.text: While the density matrix scales less favourably, 22n versus 2n for n

line_0.text: (STAB)
When scaling to large network simulations it can happen that

line_1.text: hundreds of qubits share the same entangled quantum state. For

line_2.text: such use cases, we need a quantum state representation that scales

line_3.text: sub-exponentially in time and space. NetSquid provides two such

line_4.text: representations based on the stabiliser state formalism: â€˜stabiliser

line_5.text: tableausâ€™

line_6.text: and â€˜graph states with local Cliffordsâ€™

line_7.text: (GSLC)77,78 that the user can select. Stabiliser states are a subset

line_8.text: of quantum states that are closed under the application of Clifford

line_9.text: unitaries and single-qubit measurement in the computational

line_10.text: basis. In the context of simulations for quantum networks

line_11.text: stabiliser states are particularly interesting because many network

line_12.text: protocols consist of only Clifford operations and noise can be well

line_13.text: approximated by stochastic application of Pauli gates. For a

line_14.text: theoretical comparison of the STAB and GSLC formalisms see

line_15.text: Supplementary Note 1.

line_0.text: The repetitive nature of simulation runs due to the collection of

line_1.text: statistics via random sampling allows NetSquid to take advantage

line_2.text: of â€˜memoizationâ€™ for expensive quantum operations, which is a

line_3.text: form of caching that stores the outcome of expensive operations

line_4.text: and returns them when the same input combinations reoccur to

line_5.text: save computation time. Speciï¬cally, the action of a quantum

line_6.text: operator onto a quantum state for a speciï¬c set of qubit indices

line_7.text: and other discrete parameters can be efï¬ciently stored,

line_8.text: for

line_9.text: instance as a sparse matrix. Future matching operator actions can

line_10.text: then be reduced to a fast lookup and application, avoiding several

line_11.text: expensive computational stepsâ€”see the Methods, section â€˜Qubits

line_12.text: and quantum computationâ€™ for more details.

line_0.text: Benchmarking of event-driven simulations. As explained in the

line_1.text: results section, a typical NetSquid simulation involves repeatedly

line_2.text: sampling many independent runs. As such NetSquid is â€˜embar-

line_3.text: rassingly parallelisableâ€™: the reduction in runtime scales linearly

line_4.text: with the number of processing cores available, assuming there is

line_5.text: sufï¬cient memory available. Nonetheless, given the computa-

line_6.text: tional requirements associated with collecting sufï¬cient statistics

Conclusions. In this work we have presented our design of a

line_1.text: modular software framework for simulating scalable quantum

line_2.text: networks and accurately modelling the non-idealities of real

line_3.text: world physical hardware, providing us with a design tool for

line_4.text: future quantum networks. We have showcased its power and also

line_5.text: its limitations via example use cases. Let us recap NetSquidâ€™s main

line_6.text: features.

line_0.text: First, NetSquid allows the modelling of any physical device in

line_1.text: the network that can be mapped to qubits. To demonstrate this

line_2.text: we studied two use cases involving nitrogen-vacancy centres in

line_3.text: diamond as well as atomic-ensemble based memories.

line_0.text: Second, NetSquid is entirely modular, allowing users to set up

line_1.text: large scale simulations of complicated networks and to explore

line_2.text: variations in the network design; for example, by comparing how

line_3.text: different hardware platforms perform in an otherwise identical

line_4.text: network layout. Moreover, this modularity makes it possible to

line_5.text: explore different control plane protocols for quantum networks

line_6.text: in a way that is essentially identical to how such protocols would

line_7.text: be executed in the real world. Control programmes can be run on

line_8.text: any simulated network node, exchanging classical and quantum

line_9.text: communication with other nodes as dictated by the protocol.

line_10.text: That allows users to investigate the intricate interplay between

line_11.text: control plane protocols and the physical devices dictating the

line_12.text: performance of the combined quantum network system. As an

line_13.text: example, we studied the control plane of a quantum network

line_14.text: switch. NetSquid has also already found use in exploring the

line_15.text: interplay between the control plane and the physical

line_0.text: the quantum

line_1.text: computation library used by NetSquid has been designed to

line_2.text: manage the dynamic lifetimes of many qubits across a network. It

line_3.text: offers a seamless choice of quantum state representations to

line_4.text: support different modelling use cases, allowing both a fully

line_5.text: detailed simulation in terms of wave functions or density

line_6.text: matrices, or simpliï¬ed ones using certain stabiliser formalisms.

line_7.text: As an example use case, we explored the simulation run-time of a

line_8.text: repeater chain with up to one thousand nodes.

In light of the results we have presented, we see a clear

line_1.text: application for NetSquid in the broad context of communication

line_2.text: networks. It can be used to predict performance with accurate

line_3.text: models, to study the stability of

line_4.text: large networks, to validate

line_5.text: protocol designs, to guide experiment, etc. While we have only

line_6.text: touched upon it in our discussion of performance benchmarks,

line_7.text: NetSquid would also lend itself well to the study of modular

line_8.text: quantum computing architectures, where the timing of control

line_9.text: plays a crucial role in studying their scalability. For instance, it

line_10.text: might be used to validate the microarchitecture of distributed

line_0.text: Comparison with other quantum network simulators. Let us

line_1.text: compare NetSquid to other existing quantum network simulators.

line_2.text: First, SimulaQron81 and QuNetSim82 are two simulators that do

line_3.text: not aim at realistic physical models of channels and devices, or

line_4.text: timing control. Instead, SimulaQronâ€™s main purpose is applica-

line_5.text: tion development. It is meant to be run in a distributed fashion

line_6.text: on physically-distinct classical computers. QuNetSim focuses on

line_7.text: simplifying the development and implementation of quantum

line_8.text: network protocols.

line_0.text: In contrast with SimulaQron and QuNetSim, the simulator

line_1.text: SQUANCH83 allows for quantum network simulation with

line_2.text: conï¬gurable error models at

line_3.text: layer. However,

line_4.text: SQUANCH, similar to SimulaQron and QuNetSim, does not

line_5.text: use a simulation engine that can accurately track time. Accurate

line_6.text: tracking is crucial for e.g. studying time-dependent noise such as

line_7.text: memory decoherence.

line_1.text: Design and functionality of NetSquid. The NetSquid simulator is available as a

line_2.text: software package for the Python 3 programming language. It consists of the sub-

line_3.text: packages â€˜qubitsâ€™, â€˜componentsâ€™, â€˜modelsâ€™, â€˜nodesâ€™, â€˜protocolsâ€™ and â€˜utilâ€™, which are

line_4.text: shown stacked in Fig. 10. NetSquid depends on the PyDynAA software library to

line_5.text: provide its discrete-event simulation engine80. Under the hood speed critical

line_6.text: routines and classes are written in Cython89 to give C-like performance, including

line_7.text: its interfaces to both PyDynAA and the scientiï¬c computation packages NumPy

line_8.text: and SciPy. In the following subsections we highlight some of the main design

line_9.text: features and functionality of NetSquid; for a more detailed presentation see Sup-

line_10.text: plementary Note 1.

line_0.text: Discrete event simulation. The PyDynAA package provides a fast, powerful, and

line_1.text: lightweight discrete-event simulation engine. It is a C++ port of the core engine

line_2.text: layer from the DynAA simulation framework80, with bindings added for the

line_3.text: Python and Cython languages. DynAA deï¬nes a concise set of classes and concepts

line_4.text: for modelling event-driven simulations. The simulation engine manages a timeline

line_5.text: of â€˜eventsâ€™, which can only be manipulated by objects that are sub-classes of the

line_6.text: â€˜entityâ€™ base class. Simulation entities can dynamically schedule events on the

line_7.text: timeline and react to events by registering an â€˜event handlerâ€™ object to wait for

line_8.text: event(s) with a speciï¬ed type, source entity, or identiï¬er to be triggered.

line_0.text: To deal with the timing complexities encountered in NetSquid simulations, an

line_1.text: â€˜event expressionâ€™ class was introduced to PyDynAA to allow entities to also wait

line_2.text: on logical combinations of events to occur. Atomic event expressions, which

line_3.text: describe regular wait conditions for standard events, can be combined to form

line_4.text: composite expressions using logical â€˜andâ€™ and â€˜orâ€™ operators to any depth. This

line_5.text: feature has been used extensively in NetSquid to model both the internal behaviour

line_6.text: of hardware components, as well as for programming network protocols.

line_0.text: Qubits and quantum computation. The qubits sub-package of NetSquid deï¬nes the

line_1.text: â€˜qubitâ€™ object that is used to track the ï¬‚ow of quantum information. Qubits

line_2.text: internally share quantum state (â€˜QStateâ€™) objects, which grow and shrink in size as

line_3.text: qubits interact or are measured. The â€˜QStateâ€™ class is an interface that is imple-

line_4.text: mented by a range of different formalisms, as presented in section â€˜Benchmarking

line_5.text: of quantum computationâ€™ of the Results and Discussion. Via the qubit-centric API,

line_6.text: which provides functions to directly manipulate qubits without knowledge of their

line_7.text: shared quantum states, users can programme simulations in a formalism agnostic

line_8.text: way. Functionality is also provided to automatically convert between quantum

line_9.text: states that use different formalisms, and to sample from a distribution of states,

line_10.text: which is useful for instance for pure state formalisms.

line_0.text: The ket and density matrix formalisms use dense arrays (vectors or matrices,

line_1.text: respectively) to represent quantum states. Applying a k qubit operator to an n qubit

line_2.text: ket vector state generally involves the computationally expensive task of

line_3.text: performing 2nâˆ’k matrix multiplications on 2k temporary sub-vectors and

line_4.text: aggregating the result (only in special cases can this be done in-place)90,91. The

line_5.text: analogous application of an operator to a density matrix is more expensive due to

line_6.text: the extra dimension involved. However, as discussed in section â€˜Fast and scalable

line_7.text: quantum network simulationâ€™ of the Results and Discussion, the repetitive nature

line_8.text: of NetSquid simulations allows us to take advantage of operators frequently being

line_9.text: applied to the same qubit indices for states of a given size. For these operators, we

line_10.text: compute a 2n Ã— 2n dimensional sparse matrix representation of the k qubit operator

line_11.text: via tensor products with the identity and memoize this result for the speciï¬c

line_12.text: indices and size. When the memoization is applicable the computational cost of

line_13.text: applying a quantum operator can then be reduced to just sparse matrix

line_14.text: multiplication onto a dense vector or matrix. Memoization is similarly applicable to

line_15.text: general Clifford operators in the stabiliser tableau formalism. To use memoization

line_16.text: on operators that depend on a continuous parameter, such as arbitrary rotations,

line_17.text: the parameter can be discretised i.e. rounded to some limited precision.

line_0.text: Physical modelling of network components. All physical devices in a quantum

line_1.text: network are modelled by a â€˜componentâ€™ object, and are thereby also all simulation

line_2.text: entities, as shown in Fig. 10. Components can be composed of subcomponents,

line_3.text: which makes setting up networks in NetSquid modular. The network itself, for

line_4.text: instance, can be modelled as a composite component containing â€˜nodeâ€™ and

line_5.text: â€˜connectionâ€™ components; these composite components can in turn contain com-

line_6.text: ponents such as quantum memories, quantum and classical channels, quantum

line_7.text: sources, etc., as illustrated in Fig. 1. The physical behaviour of a component is

line_8.text: described by composing it of â€˜modelsâ€™, which can specify physical characteristics

line_9.text: such as transmission delays or noise such as photon loss or decoherence. Com-

line_10.text: munication between components is facilitated by their â€˜portsâ€™, which can be con-

line_11.text: nected together to automatically pass on messages.

line_0.text: NetSquid also allows precise modelling of quantum computation capable

line_1.text: devices. For this it provides the â€˜quantum processorâ€™ component, a subclass of the

line_2.text: quantum memory. This component is capable of executing â€˜quantum programmesâ€™

line_3.text: i.e. sequences of â€˜instructionsâ€™ that describe operations such as quantum gates and

line_4.text: measurements or physical processes such as photon emission. Quantum

line_0.text: programmes fully support conditional and iterative statements, as well as

line_1.text: parallelisation if the modelled device supports it. When a programme is executed

line_2.text: its instructions are mapped to the physical instructions on the processor, which

line_3.text: model the physical duration and errors associated to carrying out the operation. A

line_4.text: physical instruction can be assigned to all memory positions or only to a speciï¬c

line_5.text: position, as well as directionally between speciï¬c memory positions in the case of

line_6.text: multi-qubit instructions.

line_0.text: Asynchronous framework for programming protocols. NetSquid provides a â€˜proto-

line_1.text: colâ€™ class to describe the network protocols and classical control plane logic run-

line_2.text: ning on a quantum network. Similarly to the component class, a protocol is a

line_3.text: simulation entity and can thereby directly interact with the event timeline. Pro-

line_4.text: tocols can be nested inside other protocols and may describe both local or remote

line_5.text: behaviour across a network. The â€˜node protocolâ€™ subclass is speciï¬cally restricted to

line_6.text: only operating locally on a single node. Inter-protocol communication is possible

line_7.text: via a signalling mechanism and a request and response interface deï¬ned by the

line_8.text: â€˜service protocolâ€™ class. Protocols can be programmed using both the standard

line_9.text: callback functionality of PyDynAA and a tailored asynchronous framework that

line_10.text: allows the suspension of a routine conditioned on an â€˜event expressionâ€™; for

line_11.text: example, to wait for input to arrive on a port, a quantum programme to ï¬nish, or

line_12.text: to pause for a ï¬xed duration.

line_0.text: The â€˜utilâ€™ sub-package shown in Fig. 10 provides a range of utilities for running,

line_1.text: recording and interacting with simulations. Functions to control the simulation are

line_2.text: deï¬ned in the â€˜simtoolsâ€™ module, including functions for inspecting and diagnosing

line_3.text: the timeline. A â€˜data collectorâ€™ class supports the event-driven collection of data

line_4.text: during a simulation, which has priority over other event handlers to react to events.

line_5.text: The â€˜simstatsâ€™ module is responsible for collecting a range of statistics during a

line_6.text: simulation run, such as the number of events and callbacks processed, the

line_7.text: maximum and average size of manipulated quantum states, and a count of all the

line_8.text: quantum operations performed. Finally, the â€˜simlogâ€™ module allows ï¬ne grained

line_9.text: logging of the various modules for debugging purposes.

line_0.text: Benchmarking. To perform the benchmarking described in section â€˜Fast and

line_1.text: scalable quantum network simulationâ€™ of the Results and Discussion we used

line_2.text: computing nodes with two 2.6 GHz Intel Xeon E5-2690 v3 (Haswell) 12 core

line_3.text: processors and 64 GB of memory. Because each process only requires a single core,

line_4.text: care was taken to ensure sufï¬cient cores and memory were available when running

line_5.text: jobs in parallel. The computation time of a process is the arithmetic average of a

line_6.text: number of successive iterations; to avoid ï¬‚uctuations due to interfering CPU

line_7.text: processes the reported time is a minimum of ï¬ve such repeated averages. To

line_8.text: perform the simulation proï¬ling the Cython extension modules of both NetSquid

line_9.text: and PyDynAA were compiled with proï¬ling on, which adds some runtime over-

line_10.text: head. Version 0.10.0 and 0.3.5 of NetSquid and PyDynAA were benchmarked. We

line_11.text: benchmarked against ProjectQ version 0.4.2 using its â€˜MainEngineâ€™ backend. See

line_12.text: Supplementary Note 2 for further details.

line_0.text: Using the same machine, simulations for Fig. 5b, c were run, which took almost

line_1.text: 260 core hours wallclock time in total, while simulations for Fig. 7 took roughly 625

line_2.text: core hours. For Fig. 4 (â‰ˆ10 h in total), Fig. 5(a) (â‰ˆ90 min) and Fig. 6 (â‰ˆ30 min), a

line_3.text: single core Intel Xeon Gold 6230 processor (3.9 GHz) with 192 GB RAM was used.

line_0.text: Implementing a processing-node repeater chain in NetSquid. Here, we explain

line_1.text: the details of the most complex of our three use cases, namely the repeater chain of

line_2.text: Nitrogen-Vacancy-based processing nodes from section â€˜Sensitivity analysis for the

line_3.text: physical modelling of a long range repeater chainâ€™ of the Results and Discussion

line_4.text: (see Supplementary Notes 3 and 7 for details on the other two use cases). We ï¬rst

line_5.text: describe how we modelled the NV hardware, followed by the repeater protocols

line_6.text: used. With regard to the physical modelling, let us emphasise that this is well

line_7.text: established (see e.g.92); the main goal here is to explain how we used this model in a

line_8.text: NetSquid implementation.

line_0.text: In our simulations the following NetSquid components model the physical

line_1.text: repeater chain: â€˜nodesâ€™, each holding a single â€˜quantum processorâ€™ modelling the

line_2.text: NV centre, and â€˜classical channelsâ€™ that connect adjacent nodes and are modelled as

line_3.text: ï¬bres with a constant transmission time. We choose equal spacing between the

line_4.text: nodes. If we were to simulate individual attempts at entanglement generation, we

line_5.text: would also need components for transmitting and detecting qubits such as was

line_6.text: used in previous NetSquid simulations of NV centres39. However, in order to speed

line_7.text: up simulations we insert the entangled state between remote NVs using a model.

line_8.text: We designed two types of protocols to run on each node of this network that differ

line_9.text: in whether they implement a scheme with or without distillation.

line_0.text: In the remainder of this section, we describe the components modelling. More
detailed descriptions of the hardware parameters and their values used in our

line_1.text: simulation can be found in Supplementary Note 4.

Simulation speedup via state insertion. For generating entanglement between the

line_1.text: electron spins of two remote NVs, we simulate a scheme based on single-photon

line_2.text: detection, following its experimental implementation in93. NetSquid was used

line_3.text: previously to simulate each generation attempt of this scheme, which includes the

line_4.text: emission of a single photon by each NV, the transmission of the photons to the

line_5.text: midpoint through a noisy and lossy channel, the application of imperfect mea-

line_6.text: surement operators at the midpoint, and the transmission of the measurement

line_7.text: outcome back to the two involved nodes39. For larger internode distances, simu-

line_8.text: lating each attempt requires unfeasibly long simulation times due to the expo-

line_9.text: nential decrease in attempt success rate. To speed up our simulations in the

line_10.text: examples studied here, we generate the produced state between adjacent nodes

line_11.text: from a model which has shown good agreement with experimental results93. This

line_12.text: procedure includes a random duration and noise induced on the storage qubits, as

line_13.text: we describe below.

NV repeater chain protocols. For the NV repeater chain, we simulated two proto-

line_1.text: cols: SWAP-ASAP and NESTED-WITH-DISTILL. Both protocols are composed of

line_2.text: ï¬ve building blocks: ENTGEN, STORE, RETRIEVE, DISTILL and SWAP. By

line_3.text: ENTGEN, we denote the simulation of the entanglement generation protocol based

line_4.text: on the description in the previous subsection: two nodes wait until a classical

line_5.text: message signals that their respective electron spins hold an entangled pair. In

line_6.text: reality, such functionality would be achieved by a link layer protocol39. STORE is

line_7.text: the mapping of the electron spin state onto a free nuclear spin, and RETRIEVE is

line_8.text: the reverse operation. The DISTILL block implements entanglement distillation

line_9.text: between two remote NVs for probabilistically improving the quality of entangle-

line_10.text: ment between two nuclear spins (one at each NV), at the cost of reading out

line_11.text: entanglement between the two electron spins. It consists of local operations fol-

line_12.text: lowed by classical communication to determine whether distillation succeeded. The

line_13.text: entanglement swap (SWAP) converts two short-distance entangled qubit pairs

line_14.text: A âˆ’ M and M âˆ’ B into a single long-distance one A âˆ’ B, where A, B and M are

line_15.text: nodes. It consists of local operations at M, including spin readout, and commu-

line_16.text: nicating the measurement outcomes to A and B, followed by A and B updating

line_17.text: their knowledge of the precise state A âˆ’ B they hold in the perfect case. We opt for

line_18.text: such tracking as opposed to applying a correction operator to bring A âˆ’ B back to a

line_19.text: canonical state since the correction operator generally cannot be applied to the

line_20.text: nuclear spins directly. Details of the tracking are given in Supplementary Note 6.

line_21.text: The circuit implementations for the building blocks, â€˜quantum programmesâ€™ in

line_22.text: NetSquid, are given in Supplementary Note 5.

line_0.text: Let us explain the SWAP-ASAP and NESTED-WITH-DISTILL protocols in

line_1.text: spirit; the exact protocols run asynchronously on each node and can be found in

line_2.text: Supplementary Note 5. In the SWAP-ASAP protocol, a repeater node performs

line_3.text: ENTGEN with both its neighbours, followed by SWAP as soon as it holds the two

line_4.text: entangled pairs. Next, NESTED-WITH-DISTILL is a nested protocol on 2n + 1

line_5.text: nodes (integer n â‰¥ 0) with distillation at each nesting level which is based on the

BDCZ protocol9. For nesting level n = 0, there are no repeaters and the two nodes

line_1.text: only perform ENTGEN once. For nesting level n > 0, the chain is divided into a left

line_2.text: part and a right part of 2nâˆ’1 + 1 nodes, and the middle node (included in both

line_3.text: parts) in the chain generates twice an entangled pair with the left end node

line_4.text: following the (n âˆ’ 1)-level protocol; STORE is applied in between to free the

line_5.text: electron spin. Subsequently, DISTILL is performed with the two pairs as input

line_6.text: (restart if distillation fails), after which the same procedure is performed on the

line_7.text: right. Once the right part has ï¬nished, the middle node performs SWAP to connect

line_8.text: the end nodes. If needed, STORE and RETRIEVE are applied prior to DISTILL and

line_9.text: SWAP in order achieve the desired conï¬guration of qubits in the quantum

line_10.text: processor, e.g. for DISTILL to ensure that the two involved NVs hold an

line_11.text: electronâ€“electron and nuclearâ€“nuclear pair of qubits, instead of electron-nuclear

line_12.text: for both entangled pairs.
